I'm about to begin producing a new video with KSP, and it is going to have music overlay for a dramatic effect. However, I want to have some captions of the crew talking to each other for a bit of time filler as well as plot development.

Does anyone have a recommendation of a font or language to use for the "Kerbal language?" My first thought was Webdings , but I'd like to know if anyone else knows of a font that would work. I'm thinking something maybe similar to the Russian alphabet, but obviously not the Russian alphabet.

I have no idea why, but I think a form of Elvish script might actually suit the Kerbals for some reason. Hobbitton Brushhand is a good one for that. Semi-legible.

My first thought was Webdings

In my headcanon it'd be wingdings, but close enough.

Obviously for human eyes, you'd need to add another layer of subtitles, superimposed on top, in comic sans.

Why does everyone hate Comic Sans?

Its not that bad

I vote for some type of cuneiform. Absolutely the most Kerbal of all writing systems. All the characters are made of parts that look like capsules, struts, and such, so the characters themselves look like typical KSP asparagus monstrosities.

Kerbals would totally use Comic Sans...

They in fact did use Comic Sans on the "not safe for children" warning in the Materials lab part.

So if you wanted a Kerbal font... Comic Sans would be it. But if you just want something quickly readable... anything Arial will do.

Is there a way we could get cuniform (good call, Geschosskopf) in comic sans?

For human-readable, Comic Sans is very Kerbal font, definitely.

For non-human readable, I kinda like Ancient Autobot, looks kinda Kerbal to me, too.

Or maybe Alien Script

Or just take a look here and pick your favorite.

You can see kerbal writing in the IVAs of certain pods.

They are all written in English.
I use Letter-o-matic for my stuff. Not sure if it's fitting for the Kerbals, but I put them on my drawings.

Several parts in the game have regular english printed on them, so I'd assume they write in english.

Maybe their langauge just happens to be english, but they pronounce everything wildly different to how we do?
Or maybe their language is backwards Spanish and they just spell everything wildly different to reverse Mexicans?
